Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Prototype and Manufacture of Small-scale Axial Permanent Magnet Generator
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to address the deficit in portable power across sectors due to a lag in innovations in battery technology. Access to portable power is a universal problem. Wearable energy harvesting devices offer part of the power solution - human motion provides enough energy over a day such that ?wasted? energy can be captured and converted to enough usable electrical energy to power a variety of portable electronics. Wearable harvesters, such as a foot charger worn in a shoe, can seamlessly integrate into a user?s natural motion without causing the user any fatigue. Therefore, wearable energy harvesting technology is applicable to a wide variety of applications, including developing regions, military/aid organizations, consumer electronics and outdoor gear. Devices that implement mechanical systems have high theoretical power to weight ratios and produce enough power to charge small mobile electronics. To improve these devices, additional optimization on the limiting feature - the PMG - is necessary.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will reduce the size and increase the efficiency of axial permanent magnet generators (PMGs) for energy harvesting applications. There are two types of PMGs used in current mechanical harvesting applications: radial and axial generators. Both produce multi-phase AC power, can be optimized for geometry and weight, and are used extensively in wind turbines on a large scale. Radials, because of their relative ease of manufacture, are designed for small-scale energy generation applications, most popularly in hand-crank generation devices. However, wearable energy harvesting applications have very strict volume requirements. The small, flat profile required for volume optimization suggests that axial PMGs are more space efficient for wearables. Essentially, to achieve a flatter profile in which height of the overall mechanism is minimized at the expense of increasing diameter, an axial generator would produce more power. The objectives of this project are to validate axial PMG simulations with physical prototypes, prove axial PMGs create a power increase of at least 10% over radial PMGs in existing commercial systems, and to evaluate the feasibility of manufacturing axial implementations at scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SolePower received the SBIR grant in Electronic Hardware for the purpose of reducing the size and increasing the efficiency of axial permanent magnet generators (PMGs) for energy harvesting applications. The goal of this project was to test physical implementations of axial permanent magnet generators to evaluate the commercial feasibility of using axial generators in future wearables. The innovation proposed is a critical step in the commercialization of wearables and mobile devices, which are currently limited by battery size. Developing small-scale axial PMGs is critical for enabling wearable energy harvesting devices in the future.

 

SolePower focused on 3 milestones: (1) validate that virtual simulations of axial PMGs are comparable to physical implementations created by either of the proposed manufacturing methods. If they are not comparable, understand by what factor they differ so that engineers can analyze the cost and benefits of integrating different generators into their wearable designs. (2) Prove that the “optimized” generators create a power increase of 10% or more power within the same volume as current radial generators. (3) Evaluate the feasibility of implementing two assembly processes (“bendable poles” and “removable poles”) at scale.

 

A permanent magnet generator consists of two components: the stator, which includes a metal base and copper coils, and the rotor, which includes a plastic structure and magnets. Using ANSYS Maxwell, an electromagnetics modeling program, SolePower analyzed variables which affect the power output of axial generators, including magnet volume, magnet strength, coil volume, coil shape, overall height, and overall diameter. Certain trends were expected and proven. For example, increasing magnet strength increased simulated power output.  SolePower selected 10 unique geometries for stators and rotors based on simulation results.  The stators were sent out for prototyping while SolePower built and programmed a mechanical rig for the purpose of testing the generators, and assembled the rotors.

 

Milestone 1 is to validate that the ANSYS simulations matched the physical implementations. The axial generators, while in the same order of magnitude as the radials in power output, were found to output on average 38% of the expected effective voltage. There are several causes for the difference between simulated and experimental results. It is most likely that the stator coils were not wound as tightly as possible, noted by comparing the same geometry generator, produced weeks apart. The generator produced later was wound more densely due to the manufacturer’s experience with the process.

 

Milestone 2 is to prove that the axial generators generate more than 10% more power than a radial generator of equivalent volume. The axial generators did not perform 10% more powerfully.  Some were, however, found to be equivalent, within the margin of error.  Although a higher power was expected, this is still a positive find.  Axial generators allow for more variability in their volume, which would allow them to be implemented more easily into wearable devices.

 

Milestone 3 is to show that axials, at medium and high volumes, are within the same price bracket. This was found to be true.  With several custom inductor winding companies’ help, SolePower was able to quote axial generators at scale at a maximum of 4 times their radial counterparts.

 

SolePower is a startup building wearable kinetic chargers. The housing that secures the energy harvesting mechanisms are “prototype cases”. The team successfully developed a prototype case with which the axial generator was tested. Selecting the most powerful version of the axial generator, as it is simulated, does not necessarily produce the most power in the overall energy harvesting system. For example, powerful generators require stiffer rotors to accommodate increases in resistance force so that, during a step, the rotor remains roughly concentric and does not interfere with the stator. In the current implementation, a rotor with less strength (N42 instead of N52 magnets) appeared to result in a faster spin.

 

The methods for prototyping and validating simulations discovered over the course of the project are critical for efficiently developing mechanical wearable chargers. Such chargers will have a tremendous impact. They will provide much needed power for wearables and phones, sensors and GPS for safety applications, and they will help meet the power needs for lighting and electronics after natural disasters and in underdeveloped regions.

 

SolePower’s long term vision is to provide a power platform for wearable, mobile devices and other portable electronics. Broadly, devices are becoming more efficient and more usable. This is seen across sectors, from entertainment devices to life-saving medical technology. But a lack of development in storage and mobile charging capabilities limit the usability these innovations. Right now, battery life limits technology. If electronics are untethered from a wall outlet and given true autonomy from power constrains, the possibilities for wearability and connectivity are limitless.
